elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, sing a song about weather, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
do that the bigger clouds couldn’t do?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules; Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or sky changes.
Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Show children a series of pictures and talk about the different types of weather they see in each one.
Challenge children to use their bodies to show how they’d act in each type of weather.
Can you find books that show pictures of different kinds of weather?
Pretend to be a cloud floating in the sky. What shape would you like to be?
Can you see clouds from the window? What shapes are they?
Draw a picture of rain clouds with lightning during a thunderstorm.
What materials can you use to make a cloud? How about a flash of lightning?
What letter makes the sound  you hear at the beginning of  the word
Can you use blocks to build a place outside where people can stay dry during a rainstorm?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder  to
Read closely to notice and talk about the  Mind Builder.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules; Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or sky changes.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.
Show children a series of pictures of clothing that is appropriate for either hot or cold weather.
Have children sort each item into a “hot” or “cold” pile and discuss how people plan for different weather conditions.
Can you find in a book a picture of a windy day?
Pretend to make hot soup to drink on a cold day. Serve some to your friends.
Can you compare Cloudette to the other clouds? Can you show it in a picture?
What is your favorite thing to do outdoors on a hot day? Draw it.
Can you make a snowman on a sheet of paper?
start with? What about the word
Build a snow castle for you and a friend. How big will it be? What shape will it be?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension strategy
, engage children in a movement activity about weather, and introduce vocabulary
want to do that the bigger clouds could do?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Tolerate frustration as a step to learning.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Review and discuss with children pictures of different types of weather.
Discuss what you would see and do and how you would feel in each type of weather.
How would that story be  different if the weather were different?
Can you show me how you  would walk down the sidewalk on a very windy day?
Can you think of a way to measure the rain? How could  you measure snow?
Can you make up a song about clouds? Draw a picture to go  with it.
How many different colors can you use to paint the sun?
What letters would you use to spell the word
Can you build a snowman out of blocks? How tall will it be?

attributes.alt:
Big Chart of Big Ideas for What's the Weather? Chart shows 4 different types of weather: rainy, snowy, windy, and sunny. 
Chart shows a child in a rain coat with an umbrella next to the word "rainy,"a child in a winter coat holding a snowball next to the word "snowy,"a child running with a kite in the grass next to the word "windy,"and two children building sandcastles at the beach next to the word "sunny."
Cover for Cloudette by Tom Lichtenheld. Cover shows a small smiling cloud and a blue sky.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about clouds and weather, sing a song about weather, and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules; Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or sky changes.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence
Provide children with blank Daily Weather books for them to record their observations about the weather they see.
Help children with making and recording observations.
Find a book about weather. What kinds of weather does it show?
Pretend to jump in a puddle.  How does it feel?
Count how many bigger clouds talk to Cloudette in the book.
Can you make a cover for your Daily Weather book? What will you show on the cover?
What do you think is the first letter? What do you think is the last letter?
Build a place where people can go when it is raining.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children do a movement activity about their favorite type of weather and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book. Ask,
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen  in the sky.
Act out to recreate and tell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What is your favorite type of weather? Why?
Save children’s writing/drawing to display next week.
Can you find a story that takes place on a sunny day?
Pretend you are on TV. Tell people what the weather will  be like tomorrow and what  they should wear when they  go outside.
Pretend you are in a bathtub full of water. What are two things that sink? What are two things that float?
Can you draw a picture of  the saying, “It’s raining cats  and dogs”?
Thunder makes the sound BOOM. Can you find the first letter in
? Can you find the last letter?
Can you make a rainbow out of blocks?
